item.title: Trump Says US Won’t Agree to Any Uranium Enrichment by Iran
item.description: The US will not allow any uranium enrichment as part of any deal with Iran under any deal the countries reach, President Donald Trump said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: An Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) speed boat is sailing along the Persian Gulf during the IRGC marine parade, which is commemorating the Persian Gulf National Day, near the Bushehr nuclear power plant in the seaport city of Bushehr, Bushehr province, in the south of Iran, on April 29, 2024. The Persian Gulf National Day, celebrated on the 10th of Ordibehesht in the Iranian calendar, usually falls in late April or early May and commemorates the expulsion of the Portuguese from the Strait of Hormuz and the Persian Gulf in 1622 by the Safavid forces led by Imam Quli Khan under the command of Shah Abbas I. (Photo by Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: Senate Begins Putting Its Stamp on Giant Trump Tax, Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump’s signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Senator Mike Crapo in Washington. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Federal Retirement Process Goes Digital, Targeting Paper Pileup
item.description: The federal personnel agency has launched an online system for processing retirement applications, ending a paper-based method that had remained largely unchanged for decades.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Vehicles drive past the Theodore Roosevelt Building, headquarters of the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Friday, June 5, 2015. The disclosure by U.S. officials that Chinese hackers stole records of as many as 4 million government workers is now being linked to the thefts of personal information from health-care companies. The hackers, thought to have links to the Chinese government, got into the OPM computer system late last year, according to one U.S. official.

item.title: For Volatile Trump, Trade Pacts With China, Europe Prove Elusive
item.description: US President Donald Trump is eager to land more trade deals, but talks with China and Europe continue to languish amid communications breakdowns and fresh tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. Trump accused China of violating an agreement with the US to ease tariffs, ratcheting up tensions between the world's two largest economies.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Hurdles at Home Are Reshaping the Mideast Financial Order
item.description: Bankers and business leaders are shifting more attention toward the kingdom’s neighbors in the Gulf as it grapples with lower oil prices and weakening finances.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Dinesh Nair, Adveith Nair

media:content.media:description: Saudi Arabia needs to bring in foreign capital to continue spending.

item.title: South Korea Votes for a New Leader to Heal Nation, Regain Growth
item.description: South Koreans head to the polls Tuesday to elect a new president to lead the nation after an attempt to impose martial law at the end of last year triggered its worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: A voter casts their ballot at a polling station in Incheon, South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Keeping Track of the Twists and Turns of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Monday, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst Nathan Dean gives his insights into what’s been happening and what’s coming up in the nooks and crannies of government and markets. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Nathan R Dean

item.title: Mexico Remittances Plunge as Trump Cracks Down on Migrants
item.description: Remittances sent to Mexico fell 12% in April from a year prior, registering the largest annual drop in more than a decade as US lawmakers mull taxing the transfers and Donald Trump’s administration toughens its rhetoric against migrants.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Customers at a money exchange outside the US Customs and Border Protection - San Ysidro Port of Entry in San Diego, California.

item.title: Senate to Review Trump ‘Revenge’ Tax Worrying Wall Street
item.description: Senate Republicans will examine the potential impact of a so-called “revenge” tax buried in President Donald Trump’s massive fiscal package before passing the measure, Majority Leader John Thune said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune, a Republican from South Dakota, speaks during a news conference following the Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, March 11, 2025. The House is scheduled to vote on a six-month spending bill that would make sure the whole government doesn't shut down, interrupting the fast start of President Donald Trump's second watch.

item.title: US Aluminum and Steel Prices Surge as Trump Doubles Tariffs
item.description: Futures tracking aluminum and steel prices in the US surged after President Donald Trump said he will double tariffs on the metals this week.
item.dc:creator: Mark Burton

item.title: Leon Black’s Son Reveals $219 Million of Assets in Ethics Filing
item.description: The son of private equity billionaire Leon Black has disclosed hundreds of millions of dollars of personal wealth as he awaits confirmation to lead an obscure federal agency.
item.dc:creator: Bill Allison, Loukia Gyftopoulou

media:content.media:description: Ben Black, founder of Fortinbras Enterprises, participates in a panel discussion during the Milken Institute Global Conference in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., on Tuesday, May 3, 2022. The event convenes the best minds in the world to tackle its most urgent challenges and to help realize its most exciting opportunities.

item.title: Dutch Coalition Risks Collapse After Failure of Migration Talks
item.description: The ruling coalition in the Netherlands failed to reach an agreement over plans pushed by the far-right Freedom Party to curb migration and is set to continue talks on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: The Binnenhof in The Hague.

item.title: Lack of Social Media Could Prompt US Visa Denial
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Friday ordered more scrutiny of the social-media profiles of any foreigners seeking to visit Harvard University, telling US consular officers that applicants’ lack of an online presence might be enough evidence to deny a visa.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Banners hang from Memorial Church on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: Kyiv’s Brazen Drone Strike on Nuclear Bombers Alarms Moscow
item.description: Ukraine’s drone strike deep inside Russian territory left Kremlin officials angry and alarmed over the sudden vulnerability of a nuclear-capable air fleet far from the battlefield, according to people close to senior officials in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A truck used to release Ukrainian drones in Irkutsk region, Russia, on June 1, in a photo released by Irkutsk region Governor Igor Kobzev. Source: Irkutsk Region Governor Igor Kobzev/AP Photo

item.title: Poland’s Tusk Calls Confidence Vote to Shore Up Support
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said he’ll seek a vote of confidence to shore up support for his coalition government after a candidate backed by his party was defeated in Sunday’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: TIRANA, ALBANIA - MAY 16: (L-R) Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk talks to the press after their meeting on May 16, 2025 in Tirana, Albania. The EPC brings together heads of state and government from the 27 European Union countries and 20 others. The items on today's agenda are security and democratic resilience, competitiveness and economic security, and mobility challenges and youth empowerment. (Photo by Leon Neal - Pool /Getty Images)

item.title: Canada Premiers Pitch Carney on New Pipelines, Ports and Mines
item.description: Canada’s provincial leaders urged Prime Minister Mark Carney to back new oil pipelines, electricity grids, critical mineral mines, ports and railways at a meeting on Monday meant to identify “nation-building” projects to be fast-tracked.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: The Port of Prince Rupert in Prince Rupert, British Columbia. One project being pitched by premiers is an economic corridor running from the western port to Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: Russian Proposals to Ukraine Seek Gas Transit Return, Tass Says
item.description: A Russian memorandum presented to Ukraine envisions the gradual restoration of diplomatic and economic ties, including with regard to natural-gas transit, the state-run Tass news service reported, citing the document.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: A section of gas pipeline crosses a river near Stryi, Ukraine.

item.title: Trump Moves to Lift Biden-Era Curbs on Arctic Oil Drilling
item.description: The Trump administration is moving to repeal Biden-era curbs blocking oil drilling across most of the mammoth petroleum reserve in Alaska that’s home to an estimated 8.7 billion barrels of recoverable oil.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: (Photo by Lance King/Getty Images) Photographer: Lance King/Getty Images North America

item.title: Starmer Torn Between Trump and Labour on UK Defense Overhaul
item.description: Keir Starmer’s revamp of defense policy intended to show both Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin that Britain is serious about maintaining its role as a key power in Europe and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, left, and US President Donald Trump shake hands during a news conference in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. The trip is seen as an opportunity for Starmer to prove himself as a global leader, defend democratic values, and make Britain stronger at home, while also navigating the complexities of dealing with Trump.

item.title: German Court Blocks Asylum Seeker Rejection in Blow to Merz
item.description: A Berlin court ruled that Germany’s controversial move to refuse entry to some asylum seekers is unlawful in a setback for Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s tougher stance on migration.
item.dc:creator: Iain Rogers

media:content.media:description: German police check vehicles arriving at a temporary border checkpoint in Frankfurt.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Agree on New Prisoner Swap But Fail to Reach Truce
item.description: Russia and Ukraine wrapped up a second round of talks in Istanbul that failed to bring the two sides closer to ending the war, but laid the groundwork for a new exchange of prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Olesia Safronova

item.title: Trump Team Pushes for Xi Call as Trade Tensions Simmer
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are likely to speak this week, the White House said, as the world’s two largest economies remain locked in trade turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI and Michele Spatari/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei’s FX Gambit Sparks Sharpest Demand for Dollars Since 2019
item.description: Demand for dollars in Argentina hit its highest since 2019 after President Javier Milei all but eliminated foreign-exchange restrictions in the crisis-prone South American nation.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

item.title: UK Isn’t Ruling Out Making Immigration Restrictions Retroactive
item.description: Immigration minister Seema Malhotra said it is still too soon to know whether the government’s plans to make it harder for migrants to claim settlement in the UK will apply retroactively to those already in the country, potentially extending the wait for millions who arrived in the country since the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Meg Short

media:content.media:description: A lifeboat carrying migrants picked up at sea attempting to cross the English Channel arrives at the Marina in Dover, England, on May 21.

item.title: Suspect in Colorado Attack Criminally Charged by US Prosecutors
item.description: The man arrested over an attack at an event in support of Israeli hostages in Gaza that left at least eight injured was criminally charged by US prosecutors in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: An Israeli flag fixed to a street sign as police stand by off Pearl Street on the scene of an attack in Boulder, Colorado, on June 1, 2025.

item.title: From AI to Nukes: Here’s What’s in the UK’s Big Defense Overhaul
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government outlined a new defense strategy on Monday that aims to put a “stronger, more lethal” North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the forefront of British defense plans as the country boosts its nuclear deterrent, rebuilds munitions and weapons stockpiles and invests billions of pounds into technologically-advanced warfare methods.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Soldiers of the British Army prepare an artillery gun during a military exercise near Hohenfels, Germany.

item.title: Trump Plans to Tap Biden’s Green Bank to Make Billions in Loans
item.description: The Trump administration plans to use a $400 billion green bank the president once sought to kill to finance billions of dollars in loans for nuclear reactors, geothermal power and critical minerals, according to details of the administration’s fiscal year 2026 budget request.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference with Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Trump Condemns Boulder Attack, Blames Lax Immigration Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump condemned an attack in Boulder, Colorado that targeted a march in support of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas and said he would work to remove the suspect in the attack from the US.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: A law enforcement official maintains police lines near the scene of an attack on the Pearl Street Mall in Boulder, Colorado on June 1.

item.title: Starmer Seeks Nuclear Build-Up in Sweeping UK Military Revamp
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer backed a sweeping overhaul of the British military yet refused to commit to the full extent of spending increases that experts said is necessary to protect the UK from growing global threats.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Ellen Milligan, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Members of staff during a visit byKeir Starmer to the BAE Systems' Govan facility, in Glasgow, on June 2.

item.title: Germany’s Proposed EV Tax Break is Insufficient, Car Lobby Says
item.description: Germany’s plan to spur businesses to purchase electric vehicles is unlikely to provide a noticeable boost to the transition away from combustion engines as it’s limited to company fleets, according to an auto industry lobby group.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Gallu

media:content.media:description: An electric vehicle charges in Bingen, Germany.
